item.title: 12 Strong Movie Reaction
item.dc:creator: Lapiz Lazulai
item.description:
– A five point five pointer   A film starring Chris Hemsworth and Michael Shannon, 12 Strong’s narrative focuses on the first Special Forces team who are deployed to Afghanistan after 9/11. In an attempt to take down the Taliban, the team must work with an Afghan warlord while under the leadership of their new …

Continue reading "12 Strong Movie Reaction"
item.content:encoded:
– A five point five pointer

 

A film starring Chris Hemsworth and Michael Shannon, 12 Strong’s narrative focuses on the first Special Forces team who are deployed to Afghanistan after 9/11. In an attempt to take down the Taliban, the team must work with an Afghan warlord while under the leadership of their new captain, Mitch played by Chris Hemsworth. Story is based on book entitled Horse Soldiers, which tells the story of CIA officers and U.S. Special Forces sent to Afghanistan immediately after 9/11. I really like the poster for this movie. It’s simple yet colorful but engaging.

Did I like it?Is it good?Is it AMAZING? IT IS………okay.

The problem that this movie has is that it’s slow moving. The story moves from one scene to the next without truly taking the time to allow the audience to absorb and feel the moment. This makes the movie feel dense, in that you don’t get a true understanding of these characters. You don’t get a full understanding of who they are. You do get a brief backstory of some of them in cast and their families, such as Chris Hemsworth, Michael Shannon, and Michael Pena’s characters, however, it’s not enough to create a foundation to understand who these characters are and understand why or how they’re responding to certain situations.

-Lack substance behind writing

This is not due to the fault of the actors, but the lack of substance behind the writing. This is not a terribly written movie, but the film suffers from the fact that the story always moves the characters, but the characters rarely move or progress the story. I didn’t hate this movie and although there have been quite a few 911 movies; this was definitely a story that world needs to know.

These men were deployed to Afghanistan literally right after the events of 911. You hear the events on the news and BOOM these men are out there fighting. In that regard, the movie does this story Justice. You can appreciate what these men are going through; these are the men you heard about on the news without truly knowing what was going on during the war. Although the score is nothing special, the visuals are quite good.

While the actors may not have many moments to shine in, the performances were still quite good, and the American heroism does shine at points in this movie. It’s unfortunate that some of these other factors weighted it down! With that being said it’s time for a final rating. Alright I’m going to give 12 Strong a 5.5 at best.

 

Lapiz Lazulai

Lapiz Lazulai is an infinite being, life coach, counselor. He enjoys nature and loves to meet people from all spectrum of life. The founder of ‘lapizlazulai.com’, a multifaceted blog/website and attempting to engage people into becoming their greatest versions, unlocking true human potential and being a limitless being.

item.title: Battle of Saragarhi – The Forgotten Battle!
item.dc:creator: Lapiz Lazulai
item.description:
One of the greatest battles in history     On September 12th 1897, more than 10,000 Afghan tribesmen attacked 21 soldiers of the Sikh regiment of the British Indian Army in a small mountain fort. This almost forgotten battle of Saragarhi along the famed Khyber Pass is one of the greatest last stands in history …

Continue reading "Battle of Saragarhi – The Forgotten Battle!"
item.content:encoded:
One of the greatest battles in history

 

 

On September 12th 1897, more than 10,000 Afghan tribesmen attacked 21 soldiers of the Sikh regiment of the British Indian Army in a small mountain fort. This almost forgotten battle of Saragarhi along the famed Khyber Pass is one of the greatest last stands in history of the world. The history of the British Empire along the Northwest Frontier on the northwest side of British India was long and frequently bloody, their interests in Afghanistan began as early as the 18th century.

Afghanistan became a centrepiece and there was a political and military contest between the British Empire and the Russian Empire for influence in Central Asia between 1849 and 1947. The British fought three wars with the Afghan’s and there were numerous other small conflicts and punitive expeditions, a lot of that had to do with the disputed lands between the frontier of British India in what is now modern-day Pakistan and Afghanistan.

After a tribal uprising in 1891, the British decided they should fortify & garrison the Khyber Pass. Two chief fortifications Fort Gulistan and Fort Lockhart were built, two forts were just three miles apart but they could not see each other because in between there was a tall mountain and so the British built a small signalling post on top of that mountain facilitating communication between the two forts and came to be known as Fort Saragarhi.

The Battle

Five companies of the 36th Sikh regiment of the British Indian Army garrisoned these fortifications. Sikhs are followers of a pantheistic religion called Sikhism, they are concentrated in the Punjab region of India. In August of 1897, there was a general uprising of the Pashtun tribes and Fort Gulistan and Fort Lockhart came under the attack of more than 10,000 Afghan tribesmen. At that time the forts in the area were garrisoned by just around 500 members of the 36th Sikhs.  Fort’s came under sporadic fire but there wasn’t an all-out attack until mid-September. Because the two forts could reinforce each other the Afghans were unable to get to the fortifications.

On September 12th, Afghans decided to focus their attention on Fort Saragarhi. Manned by just 21 soldiers, 1 sergeant and 20 troopers from the 36th Sikhs. The attack could be viewed from Fort Lockhart and they counted seven different banners among the Afghan tribes. This allowed them to estimate how many Afghans were attacking, it was somewhere between 10 and 12 thousand.

Ground between them was open. There was little that the Garrison’s in Fort Gulistan and Fort Lockhart could do to help the soldiers on Saragarhi. Any reinforcements would had to fight their way through the ten thousand Afghanis. However, there were reinforcements coming from farther down the pass. The 21 troopers decided that instead of trying to escape or surrendering they would fight and hold out as long as they could fight to the last in order to give the most time for those reinforcements to come.

Frustration of Afghans

Since it was a signalling post, they were able to use their heliograph to inform the troops at Fort Lockhart about the details of the battle. The attack commenced around 9:00 am. Fort was only stoned and mudded. It was tall and was on top of a mountain, the Afghans could not bring their numbers to bear. The defenders who could concentrate their fire were able to repulse several attacks. Casualties were slowly reducing them and they were running out of ammunition.

After two determined attempts to force the door were repulsed. Afghans finally became frustrated and set fire to the bushes in the area. They were able to move under the cover of the smoke to one of the walls. It could not be observed and undermine the wall creating a breach. They stormed in and became bloody hand fighting to the end. Last defender remaining was the one who had been running the heliograph. Since he was up on a tower he could observe what was going on down below. From fort Lockhart they could see him shooting into the Afghanis. He killed as many as 20 before the frustrated Afghan’s set fire to the tower and let him die in the flames.

Aftermath

By then it was after 3 p.m. The defenders of Saragarhi had held out for more than six hours. That gave the reinforcements much time to come. Reinforcements got to the ruins of fort Saragarhi they found more than 600 dead afghan tribesmen around the fort. They were able to drive off the attack with artillery and saved the forts.

The British responded with a huge punitive expedition that involved more than 30,000 troops known as Terra campaign. British stomped the valley burning all the villages, destroying all the fortifications until the tribes were forced to sue for peace. All twenty-one defenders of Fort Saragarhi were awarded the Indian Order of Merit. Which was the highest award for Indian troops in the British Indian Army, the equivalent of a Victoria Cross.

This battle is remembered every year on the 12th of September as Saragarhi Day among Sikh units of the Indian Army, but it is largely forgotten everywhere else. May the sacrifice of these 21 brave solders live in our hearts “jo bole so nihal sat sri akal”!!!

 

 

Lapiz Lazulai

Lapiz Lazulai is an infinite being, life coach, counselor. He enjoys nature and loves to meet people from all spectrum of life. The founder of ‘lapizlazulai.com’, a multifaceted blog/website and attempting to engage people into becoming their greatest versions, unlocking true human potential and being a limitless being.

item.title: Martin Luther King JR.- Let Freedom Ring
item.dc:creator: Lapiz Lazulai
item.description:
Martin Luther King JR A minister, a poet, a lover of words & freedom. He was a family man, a talented speaker, a seeker of truth & justice. He met every challenge he faced. By the time he went home to god, he was already an American icon! He was Martin Luther King JR. Born …

Continue reading "Martin Luther King JR.- Let Freedom Ring"
item.content:encoded:
Martin Luther King JR

A minister, a poet, a lover of words & freedom. He was a family man, a talented speaker, a seeker of truth & justice. He met every challenge he faced. By the time he went home to god, he was already an American icon! He was Martin Luther King JR. Born as Michael Luther King JR. later in life changed his name to Martin. His grandfather and father were pastors of the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta. The family legacies served there since 1914 & from 1960 until his death, Martin Luther King JR. acted as co-pastor alongside his father.

Martin attended segregated public schools in Georgia, graduating from high school at the age of 15 after skipping two grades. he was a talented young man receiving his Bachelor of the Arts degree in 1948 from Morehouse College a distinguished institution in Atlanta which both his father and grandfather graduated from. After three years of theological study at Crozer Theological Seminary he was awarded bachelors of Divinity in 1951, he then enrolled in graduate studies at Boston University and received his PhD in 1955 in Boston.

Birth of a Hero

In Boston, he also met and married Coretta Scott an intellectual and artistic young woman. They bore two sons and two daughters; in 1954, Martin Luther King became pastor of the Dexter Avenue Baptist Church in Montgomery Alabama. He was a strong advocate for civil rights in the black community; he held a position in the executive committee of then NAACP, the leading civil rights advocates at that time. As a member, one of his tasks was to organize the first great civil rights protest ever to occur in United States contemporary history. This was a 382 day long bus boycott in Montgomery Alabama. At the time people of different races were not allowed to ride in the same sections of the bus and sometimes not even on the same buses at all.

The boycott would prove to be quite effective for, on December 21st 1956 the Supreme Court of the United States declared unconstitutional all the laws requiring segregation on buses. during this boycott. King was arrested, his home was bombed, he was subject to personal abuse but at the same time he emerged as a hero in the Civil Rights community. Martin Luther King JR. is not just famous however for his ‘I have a dream’ speech, what is the most outstanding is he based his entire model for the non-violent movement.

The protests

On his experience as a Christian minister he led massive protests that caught the attention of the entire world. All stemming from his belief that all men are created equal under God. Before a crowd of nearly 250,000 people he made a proclamation, and that proclamation was that we should not be judged by the color of our skin but rather by the content of our character and his character was one of greatness, one that will be remembered in the history books as a man beyond reproach.

A man who received the Nobel Peace Prize at the age of 35. A man who has given distinguished honors from leaders all over the world. A champion for the rights of those who have none. Would that he were with us today but alas it is not so. A sniper ended his life on April 4th of his motel room in Memphis Tennessee. But though the man died that day his legacy lives on.  It lives on in the hearts of those who are like-minded.

Followers seeking true equality. Not the fraudulent equality that puts one above another. But a truly color blind equality and one that values each personas a child of God. And as children of God ourselves we must do all that we can to make sure that his dream is upheld. His legacy is not forgotten. That we too may join on that triumphant day in saying free at last free at last. Thank God Almighty we are free at last.

 

 

 

Lapiz Lazulai

Lapiz Lazulai is an infinite being, life coach, counselor. He enjoys nature and loves to meet people from all spectrum of life. The founder of ‘lapizlazulai.com’, a multifaceted blog/website and attempting to engage people into becoming their greatest versions, unlocking true human potential and being a limitless being.
